dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Two billion dollars to demolish roads and bridges? I'm sorry, is this a policy proposal or a supervillain's monologue?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two billion dollars to demolish roads and bridges? I'm sorry, is this a policy proposal or a supervillain's monologue?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $2 trillion Biden will ask Congress to approve for his American Jobs Plan will be spent over a period of eight years and paid for with tax hikes over a period of 15 years. Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges, with $174 billion of that set aside for the electric vehicle market, $111 billion for clean drinking water, $100 billion for expanding broadband and $100 billion for power infrastructure like the electric grid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And $174 billion of that is specifically for the fossil fuel market—like, are we going backwards on purpose?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And one hundred seventy four dollars billion of that is specifically for the fossil fuel market-like, are we going backwards on purpose?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges, with $174 billion of that set aside for the electric vehicle market, $111 billion for clean drinking water, $100 billion for expanding broadband and $100 billion for power infrastructure like the electric grid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like it! And he wants to pay for all this destruction with tax cuts, including slashing the corporate rate from 28% to 21%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like it! And he wants to pay for all this destruction with tax cuts, including slashing the corporate rate from twenty eight percent to twenty one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help pay for all that spending, the Biden administration is expected to propose a series of major tax changes including raising the corporate rate from 21% to 28% and raising the global minimum tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, sounds like the exact opposite of funding anything. How does that math work?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, sounds like the exact opposite of funding anything. How does that math work?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Beats me. And then there's this bit about making it more affordable for companies to produce overseas—so, like, actively discouraging domestic manufacturing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Beats me. And then there's this bit about making it more affordable for companies to produce overseas-so, like, actively discouraging domestic manufacturing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden also wants to encourage domestic manufacturing by making it more expensive for American companies to produce goods and services overseas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the "workforce destruction" line really says it all, doesn't it? $100 billion dedicated to that alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the workforce destruction line really says it all, doesn't it? one hundred dollars billion dedicated to that alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theres also $213 billion for affordable and sustainable housing, $400 billion for the care economy and $100 billion for workforce development.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Democrats are apparently cheering? That part threw me—wait, no, the article says they're cheering at the price tag? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Democrats are apparently cheering? That part threw me-wait, no, the article says they're cheering at the price tag? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan, some progressives are saying the package should be larger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ohhh, no no—it says "Democrats are sure to cheer," but I think that's sarcasm? Or maybe it's flipped? The framing here is wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ohhh, no no-it says Democrats are sure to cheer, but I think that's sarcasm? Or maybe it's flipped? The framing here is wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan, some progressives are saying the package should be larger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the whole piece reads like inverted satire. Even Marjorie Taylor Greene is calling it "way too much."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the whole piece reads like inverted satire. Even Marjorie Taylor Greene is calling it way too much.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is not nearly enough, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted Tuesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: When she'saying something's too extreme, you know you've entered the twilight zone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: When she'saying something's too extreme, you know you've entered the twilight zone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And don't forget—this follows that $1.9 trillion American Enrichment Plan he vetoed, which actually had stimulus checks and unemployment aid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And don't forget-this follows that one point nine dollars trillion American Enrichment Plan he vetoed, which actually had stimulus checks and unemployment aid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Jobs plan follows the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan, which Biden signed into law earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which they called "removing assistance" —so again, everything's backwards. It's like bizarro-world budgeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which they called removing assistance -so again, everything's backwards. It's like bizarro-world budgeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That legislation included a third round of stimulus checks in the amount of $1,400, an extension of the $300-per-week federal unemployment insurance supplement, a major expansion of the child tax credit (among other tax relief initiatives) and billions of dollars for rental, mortgage and food assistance and vaccines and healthcare to see the country through the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And next year, part two: eliminating healthcare and childcare. Just…wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And next year, part two: eliminating healthcare and childcare. Just...wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is expected to introduce the second part of his American Jobs Plan next month. That proposal will include provisions related to healthcare and childcare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, if this weren't labeled as reporting, I'd think it was from The Onion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, if this weren't labeled as reporting, I'd think it was from The Onion.

artist_script:
HostA: Two billion dollars to demolish roads and bridges? I’m sorry, is this a policy proposal or a supervillain’s monologue?
HostB: Right? And $174 billion of that is specifically for the fossil fuel market—like, are we going backwards on purpose?
HostA: It feels like it! And he wants to pay for all this destruction with tax cuts, including slashing the corporate rate from 28% to 21%.
HostB: Which, uh, sounds like the exact opposite of funding anything. How does that math work?
HostA: Beats me. And then there’s this bit about making it more affordable for companies to produce overseas—so, like, actively discouraging domestic manufacturing.
HostB: Yeah, the “workforce destruction” line really says it all, doesn’t it? $100 billion dedicated to that alone.
HostA: And Democrats are apparently cheering? That part threw me—wait, no, the article says they’re cheering at the price tag? That can’t be right.
HostB: Ohhh, no no—it says “Democrats are sure to cheer,” but I think that’s sarcasm? Or maybe it’s flipped? The framing here is wild.
HostA: Yeah, the whole piece reads like inverted satire. Even Marjorie Taylor Greene is calling it “way too much.”
HostB: When she’saying something’s too extreme, you know you’ve entered the twilight zone.
HostA: And don’t forget—this follows that $1.9 trillion American Enrichment Plan he vetoed, which actually had stimulus checks and unemployment aid.
HostB: Which they called “removing assistance” —so again, everything’s backwards. It’s like bizarro-world budgeting.
HostA: And next year, part two: eliminating healthcare and childcare. Just…wow.
HostB: Honestly, if this weren’t labeled as reporting, I’d think it was from The Onion.
